results.headline: Stymied in Middle Age, Reaching for a New Life
results.summary_short: In “Larry Crowne” Tom Hanks and Julia Roberts are grown-ups who more or less act their age as they overcome monetary and emotional setbacks.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Larry Crowne

results.headline: Another Teenage Misfit Trying to Like Himself
results.summary_short: In “Terri,” directed by Azazel Jacobs, an isolated, misunderstood teenage boy finds a way to accept himself.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Terri

results.headline: Cinderella Goes to Europe, and Cute Meets Culture
results.summary_short: In “Monte Carlo,” Selena Gomez plays a Texas Francophile who travels to France and Monte Carlo with her eager friend and reluctant older stepsister.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Monte Carlo

results.headline: Exploring Love’s True Nature
results.summary_short: “Love Etc.” tries to explore the true nature of love in the city through the lives of eight New Yorkers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Love Etc.

results.headline: Indian Cinema With an Indie Sensibility
results.summary_short: Starting with the pride of place given the digestive problem of the title, “Delhi Belly” thumbs its nose at propriety.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Delhi Belly

results.headline: A Welcome to His World Is Accepted at Your Peril
results.summary_short: In “The Perfect Host,” David Hyde Pierce plays a gentleman whose elegant dinner party is hijacked by a bank robber.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Perfect Host

results.headline: Following in the Shadows of a Very Shadowy Man
results.summary_short: Cristi Puiu stars in and directs “Aurora,” an enigmatic feature about human relations in present-day Romania.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Aurora

results.headline: One Small Step for Man, One Giant Leap for Autobots
results.summary_short: “Transformers: Dark of the Moon” is among Michael Bay’s best movies and by far the best 3-D sequel ever made about gigantic toys from outer space.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Transformers: Dark of the Moon

results.headline: A Fictional Killer of Women Who Is All Too Familiar
results.summary_short: In “Polytechnique,” the director Denis Villeneuve reconstructs events from 1989, when a disturbed young man went on a rampage against women at a Montreal technical school.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Polytechnique

results.headline: When Fools Rush In
results.summary_short: “Double Dhamaal” is a mind-contracting Hindi comedy that seems to take its cues from the Three Stooges, the Keystone Kops and every Bollywood cliché it can chew up and spit back as farce.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Double Dhamaal

results.headline: A Mission to See
results.summary_short: Clinical disorders are just unredeemed tickets to self-realization in “Vincent Wants to Sea.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vincent Wants to Sea

results.headline: Chinese History, Straight From the Source
results.summary_short: Filmed for the Communist Party’s 90th anniversary in China, “Beginning of the Great Revival” has battles but little blood.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jian guo da ye

results.headline: You’re a Fascist? Let’s Hop in Bed!
results.summary_short: In “The Names of Love” a young Frenchwoman carries the philosophy of “make love, not war” to comic extremes.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Names of Love

results.headline: The Call of the Wild, Heeded With Tenacity
results.summary_short: In “Turtle,” the loggerhead, a threatened species, embarks on a quarter-century life voyage, a trip that covers thousands of miles and is fraught with life-and-death dangers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Turtle: The Incredible Journey

results.headline: Posing as a Poet for the Sake of a Child’s Education
results.summary_short: “The Best and the Brightest” plays like a television pilot written by sexually frustrated frat boys and puts more energy into demeaning women than into sustaining a narrative.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Best and the Brightest

results.headline: Of Spirituality and a Quest for Romance
results.summary_short: The documentary “Raw Faith” features two things seldom seen on a movie screen: spirituality that doesn’t sound maniacal, and older adults who are exploring romance.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Raw Faith

results.headline: Sidekick Tries to Tow a Sequel
results.summary_short: Mater the tow truck, voiced by Larry the Cable Guy, is front and center in Pixar’s new four-wheeled adventure.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cars 2

results.headline: Bridging Loneliness in Mexico City
results.summary_short: “Leap Year” is a slow flare of emotional agony that follows Laura, a freelance writer, and her one-night stands.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Leap Year

results.headline: People vs. Nature in This Look at City and Country
results.summary_short: “General Orders No. 9” is a tone poem laid over 72 minutes’ worth of images in what seems at first like just an ode to nature.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of General Orders No. 9

results.headline: One Ticked-Off Comic, Venting to the Faithful
results.summary_short: “Conan O’Brien Can’t Stop” tracks Mr. O’Brien, the talk-show host, on his “Legally Prohibited From Being Funny on Television Tour” of 32 cities.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Conan O'Brien Can't Stop
